titleCn: Google实验室内幕：构建Gemini编码智能体Jules——从200万token上下文到自主编程的未来
titleEn: AIE CODE Preview: Inside Google Labs - Building The Gemini Coding Agent with Jed Borovik

chapters.title: 介绍与开场
chapters.summary: 介绍了播客的主题和嘉宾Jed Borovic，并提及录制环境的背景。

chapters.title: 纽约科技圈观察
chapters.summary: Jed分享了他在纽约科技圈的观察，指出纽约的多元产业推动了科技的发展。

chapters.title: 黑客马拉松与教育
chapters.summary: 讨论了纽约地区的黑客马拉松活动及其对科技热情的激发作用。

chapters.title: AI旅程与Stable Diffusion
chapters.summary: Jed讲述了他的AI旅程，特别是对Stable Diffusion的早期接触和影响。

chapters.title: 谷歌实验室与合作
chapters.summary: 介绍了谷歌实验室的创新模式及与DeepMind的合作关系。

chapters.title: 编码Agent的未来
chapters.summary: 探讨了未来自动化编码Agent的设计及其对编程的影响。

chapters.title: AI工程与行业会议
chapters.summary: 讨论了AI工程领域的会议交流对行业发展的重要性。

chapters.title: 编程生产力与招聘
chapters.summary: 探讨了AI对编程生产力的影响以及未来招聘的趋势。

captions.zh:
欢迎来到EchoMind回声思维。

您现在收听的这期播客，是对原英文博客基于 AI 技术生成的中文版本。我们不仅搬运优质内容，还保留原汁原味的嘉宾音色。

我是Lorraine，在互联网大厂从事数据科学，同时也是一名 AI 爱好者。

从GitHub Universe大会到纽约的科技界，我们将带你探讨东西海岸的创新差异。在这期中，Jed Borovic分享了他在纽约科技圈的独特观察，揭示了大都市如何通过多元化行业推动技术发展。我们还将深入了解GitHub与Agent HQ的新合作，为开发者带来的全新机遇。无论是时尚、媒体还是金融，纽约的科技氛围正在重塑创新的界限，为未来的科技领袖提供了无限可能。



好，让我们开始吧。
captions.en: [Intro]

captions.zh: 好的，Jed Borovic，欢迎来到lanespace。
captions.en: Okay, Jed Borovic, welcome to lanespace.

captions.zh: 谢谢邀请我来。
captions.en: Yeah, thanks for having me.

captions.zh: 我们现在就在这个漂亮的播客录音室里，GitHub Universe上见面。到目前为止感觉怎么样？
captions.en: So we're sitting here@f.ins beautiful podcast studios, and we're actually meeting at GitHub Universe. How's it been so far?

captions.zh: 挺好的。今天的主题演讲很棒。看到Jules上台挺有意思的。我们团队有很多人在这儿，Jules和GitHub合作了新的Agent HQ步骤，我们都很期待。而且这个播客录音室也很赞，所以能在这儿录制我很兴奋。
captions.en: It's been great. I mean, yeah, the keynote today was awesome. It was fun to see Jules up there a little bit. We have a lot of folks from our team here. Jules is partnering with GitHub for the new Agent HQ step, which we're excited about. And also this is an incredible podcast space. So, yeah, I'm excited to do this here.

captions.zh: 很高兴他们借给我们这个空间。你还是AI Engineer Code的主持人，挺激动的。在纽约，你上大学的地方，不过你现在不住那儿了。
captions.en: I'm glad for them to loan us this space. You are also an emcee for AI Engineer Code. That's exciting. In New York, where you went to college but you don't live there anymore.

captions.zh: 对啊，我在纽约待了挺长时间的。参与纽约的科技圈挺有意思的。我觉得在那儿办大型会议挺好的。虽然西海岸有很多活动，但作为东海岸的科技人，在那边有活动真不错。
captions.en: Yeah, no, I spent a bunch of time in New York. It's funny being part of the New York tech scene. I actually think it's great having big major conferences there. There's a lot obviously that happens on the west coast, but being someone in tech on the east coast, it's just awesome to have stuff there. So.

captions.zh: 对啊，你说你经常飞去旧金山，那东海岸这边的情况怎么样？我们对这儿还挺新的，这是我们第一次来纽约。纽约这儿还有什么有意思的事儿？你觉得纽约科技圈有哪些亮点？
captions.en: Yeah, you mentioned you fly over to SF a lot and like. Like, what's it. What's the scene like in the East Coast? Like, like, obviously we are pretty new. We're like, this is our first year coming to New York. What else happens in the New York. Like, what are the highlights for you in the New York tech scene?

captions.zh: 是啊，我觉得这儿真是太多东西了。纽约这么大个城市，事情很多嘛。科技当然是其中一大块，但还有很多其他行业，像时尚、媒体、金融什么的。我觉得这些都推动了科技的发展，做了很多事情。总之，东海岸真是个不错的地方。
captions.en: Yeah, I mean, there's so much. There's, you know, obviously a ton of great companies. I think the thing that's interesting about New York is it's such a big city with so much going on. Right. And so there's like, you know, tech is a huge part of it, but there's also, you know, so many major industries there, whether it's fashion, media, fashion, finance. Like, it's like, I think that helps push the tech and do. Do all kinds of stuff. But yeah, no, the east coast is a great city.

captions.zh: 太好了。
captions.en: Great.

captions.zh: 你知道，东海岸有很多优秀的学校，学生们在做各种有趣的事情。我就是在那里上的大学，那边的黑客马拉松特别棒。我就是在那里爱上了科技和编程。
captions.en: You know, the, the. All the schools there's, you know, all across the east coast, ton of great schools and great students doing all kinds of stuff. So, yeah, you know, I went to school there. The hackathon scene there was amazing. Really fell in love with tech and, and programming there.

captions.zh: 那纽约大学有没有像斯坦福那样的大型黑客马拉松活动，比如像Calhacks那种的？
captions.en: So is there a big NYU hackathon like, like in Stanford with like, Calhacks and stuff?

captions.zh: 对，有个叫Tree Hacks的活动。这个是很久以前的事了，是纽约大学和哥伦比亚大学一起办的。我们一起搞了很多活动，叫Hack and Y。把纽约各地的学生都聚到一起，特别好玩。
captions.en: Yeah, so there's a tree hacks. Yeah, there's one that was put on by. This was a while ago, but we put on by NYU in Columbia. We do together. Hack and Y. So there's a bunch of events kind of that we did together. It would bring, you know, people across New York City, students across New York City. And those are super fun.

captions.zh: 对啊。
captions.en: Yeah.

captions.zh: 所以有时候在哥大办，有时候在纽约大学办，两边轮流。嗯，那里做出了很多很酷的东西。
captions.en: So it'd be at Columbia one time and then NYU the next, and it would cycle back and forth. So, yeah, a lot of cool stuff was made there.

captions.zh: 不错哦。你在谷歌工作了好几年了，九年呢。你做了很多项目，包括和Malta合作，他也是我今天采访的嘉宾之一。那你是怎么接触到Juuls的？AI之旅是怎么开始的？
captions.en: Nice. So you've been at Google for a while. Nine years. You worked on a bunch of things, including with Malta, which is also another guest that I'm interviewing today. How do you get into Juuls? What's the AI journey?

captions.zh: 嗯，这听起来可能有点老套，但我跟好多人讲过这个故事，就是他们问我怎么做这行的。其实是真的。我在搜索工作了很久，专注于新闻和时效性。然后，当stable diffusion出来时，对我来说，那是第一代的AI模式。虽然大家都说ChatGPT是第一个，但对我来说，stable diffusion比ChatGPT早了几个月。这是个大事，我在网上追了很多。有两个创作者群体对它反应不同，一个群体觉得这是在偷他们的艺术，偷他们珍视的一切。
captions.en: Yeah, so this is gonna sound really cheesy, but I've told the story a couple times to folks when they're like, oh, how'd you end up doing this? But it is actually very true. So I worked on Search for a long time and specifically kind of like news and freshness. And then when stable diffusion came out, that to me was the first gen AI mode. I know it's people talk about ChatGPT as the first thing, but for me, stable diffusion was a couple months before ChatGPT came out. It was a huge thing and I was fall it a ton online. And there were two groups of creators having reactions to it. You know, there was one group that was, you know, this is stealing my art. This is stealing everything that's near and dear to me.

captions.zh: 我讨厌这样。
captions.en: I hate this.

captions.zh: 这简直毁了我的生活。不过还有另一群艺术家和创作者觉得，哦，这其实是个能创作更好艺术的工具。我当时就在观察这些动态。对，就是这样。差不多那时候，我和几个人聊，他们说，如果我有个孩子在上大学，我不会建议他们学计算机科学。我当时就想，啥？为什么？这还是在Jensen Huang和其他人说这些话之前。我就很惊讶，为什么呢？他们说，哦，AI软件工程会变，谁知道以后还有没有工作。我当时就想，我喜欢做软件工程师，喜欢编程。然后我想，这就是我的stable diffusion时刻——要么它会夺走我的艺术和技艺，要么它是个能创作更好艺术的工具。我很清楚自己要选哪条路。所以我开始非常投入地做编程。虽然还在做搜索，但我花了很多时间在自己喜欢的项目上，玩各种东西，最后找到了一个最让我兴奋的职位，就是加入谷歌实验室和Juuls。那时候我们正开始在谷歌开发这种编程agent。时机刚好，我就加入了，真的很棒。
captions.en: This is ruining my life. And there was another group of artists and creators who were like, oh, this is a tool to create better art. And so I was watching this in your brush. Yeah, exactly. And right around then, I was having conversations with a couple people who would say things like, you know, if I had a kid in college, I wouldn't recommend they study computer science. I was like, what? Why? And this was long before Jensen Huang and people had been saying this kind of stuff. I was like, whoa, why? And it was like, oh, AI software engineering is going to change. It's going to be so who knows if there are going to be jobs? And I was like, I love being a software engineer, I love programming. And I was like, wait, this is my stable diffusion moment. This is either it's going to take my art, my craft, this is a tool to create better art. And I was like, I definitely know which path I'm taking. So I got very into building coding. So I was still working on Search, but I spent a bunch of time making stuff, my own time and playing with things, and ultimately tried to find a role that would the most exciting role I could find to do this stuff. And that was to join Google Labs and Juuls where we were right around then we're starting to build these kind of coding agents at Google. And yeah, the timing worked out well and I joined and yeah, it's been awesome.

captions.zh: 既然我们聊到谷歌实验室，我其实不太清楚谷歌实验室、DeepMind和谷歌其他部门是怎么分的。组织架构是怎样的呢？
captions.en: Since we're talking about Google Labs, I am actually unclear about where Google Labs starts and then DeepMind and the rest of Google. What is the org chart layer?

captions.zh: 嗯嗯，这个问题问得好。谷歌实验室的使命就是开发一些谷歌其他部门暂时不太适合的新产品。
captions.en: Yeah, yeah, that's a great question. So Labs mission is to build kind of new innovative products that the rest of Google isn't well positioned for.

captions.zh: 嗯，我们从Nopagalm那边开始发展起来的。
captions.en: Yeah, which we've had like rise up from Nopagalm.

captions.zh: 对，对，可能是最广泛的，最主要的。
captions.en: Exactly, exactly. Maybe the most wide, the mostly.

captions.zh: 然后它叫做nanobanana。我也不太确定是不是这个名字。
captions.en: And then it's called nanobanana. I don't know if it's.

captions.zh: 嗯，谷歌实验室特别让人兴奋的一点是，我们和DeepMind的合作非常紧密。我们在开发产品的时候，主要是为了模型的部分跟他们合作。身在谷歌的好处之一就是，你有机会从头到尾打造一个AI产品，从页面上的像素到基础设施，再到模型和训练的整个过程。实验室的目标就是开发新产品，我们其实就是一个产品组织，但是真正的AI产品组织，不仅和DeepMind紧密合作，也会根据需要和谷歌的其他部门合作。
captions.en: Yeah, so some of the. So the thing about that's really exciting about Labs is we work incredibly closely with DeepMind. Right. So all the stuff in terms of the, you know, we're building a product but we work so closely mostly for the model. And one of the nice things about being at Google is you have this opportunity to really build an end to end AI product right from pixels on the page, through the infrastructure, through the model and the training and all of that loop. So Labs is here to build new products and we're really like a product org, but a true AI product org where we work incredibly closely with DeepMind but also other parts of Google as it makes sense.

captions.zh: 嗯，我听说谷歌内部其实有个类似Copilot的AI编程工具，但从没发布过。这是真的吗？能不能聊聊这个？
captions.en: Yeah, just on the history of AI coding, I had heard that actually Google had an internal version of Copilot or something like that that was never released. Is that true? What can we say about it?

captions.zh: 嗯，你知道，其实谷歌在这方面已经发表了不少论文，所以我们在谷歌内部开发了很多自己的工具。像cidr，可能有的人听说过，这是我们的内部IDE。我们在这方面有各种功能和工具，所以是的，我们确实有一些很不错的工具，但这些工具主要是给内部使用的。
captions.en: Yeah, so you know, I think there are, there are, you know, Google's published papers in this space for a while and so yeah, we have, you know, in Google we built a lot of our own tools and you know, cidr, which you know, folks maybe have heard of is our, you know, our internal ide and we've had all kinds of, you know, capabilities and tools there for a while. So yes, you know, we certainly have had pretty good tools for a while, but they were for internal use.

captions.zh: 对，我觉得挺有意思的。当谷歌开始涉足那种类似LM的领域时，基本上就是一切都重新命名为Gemini，开始搞Gemini的时候，人们就会想，哦，你知道吗，谷歌的整个代码库可能跟GitHub的差不多大，里面肯定有些有趣的数据。
captions.en: Yeah, yeah, I think, I think it was interesting because like, I think one of the hype moments when Google started getting into the sort of like LM game, like basically when everything rebranded to become Gemini and like starting to start Gemini, where people are like, oh, did you know that Google probably like Google's entire repo is probably about the same size as GitHub and like, you know, there must be some interesting data in there.

captions.zh: 哦，对啊，构建这些内部系统的时候，数据真是太厉害了。
captions.en: Oh yeah, I Mean, and that's one of the things, you know, in building a lot of these internal systems, the data is incredible.

captions.zh: 对啊。
captions.en: Yeah.

captions.zh: 特别是你知道的，不仅模型和训练都是内部的，使用数据什么的也都是。所以我们能在这方面做出很厉害的东西。
captions.en: Especially when it's, you know, not only is the model and the training in house, but all the data on the usage and whatever. So, you know, we could build really kind of sophisticated things there.

captions.zh: 好，那我们来介绍一下你们网站上的Jules，就是那个自动化编码agent。我们见过很多这样的东西，不过它们不是章鱼，也不是紫色的，这方面你们有自己的特色。但在这个竞争激烈的编码agent领域，你们真正想做到的核心是什么呢？
captions.en: Yeah. Okay, so let's introduce people to Jules on your website says Jules, Autonomous coding agents. We've seen lots of these. They're not octopuses, they're not purple. So you got that going for you. But what really is the core thing you're trying to nail in a very crowded coding agents landscape.

captions.zh: 嗯，我们当初开始做的时候就在想，编码agent将来会怎么样？随着这些模型越来越强大和复杂，那种体验会是什么样的？我们想为未来打造这样的东西。想象一个非常强大的agent，可以长时间运行，处理非常复杂的事情，这就是我们的产品开始成型的时候。比如说，自动化意味着它有自己的计算机。对，没错。很多agent是在本地或者你的工作环境中运行的，但如果你想要一个能运行好几个小时，甚至几天的东西，你可能希望它有自己的环境来完成工作。这是这个自动化编码agent重要的一部分。我们在想象一个非常强大的未来，你可以随时启动很多这样的agent。它们是自主的，但我们也在思考什么是“环境化”。比如说，当它有自己的基础设施、计算机，还有自己的交互方式时，这会如何改变它的能力？举个例子，我们有一个API，人们用它来做各种事情，比如在某些事件发生时触发它。我们看到有例子是用Jules做网站更新，然后用GitHub action自动合并Jules的pull request。所以，各种东西都在流动，真的改变了人们做事的方式。
captions.en: Yeah. So what we think about and what we set out to do back when I joined was like, where are coding agents going to go? And as these models get more and more powerful and sophisticated, what is that experience going to be? And let's build for that future. And so when you think of a really powerful agent that can run for a really long time doing really complicated things, that's when the products started to take shape for us. So for example, autonomous means it has its own computer. So for Juuls, it's the end. Yeah, exactly. So tons of agents that run locally or in your workspace with you while you're coding. But if you want something that's going to run for hours or let's say days, you might want it to have its own environment where it can do its own work. So that's one of the pieces that's important for this autonomous coding agent. But it's really like, you know, think about this future where they're incredibly powerful. You can spin up tons of them. Right. They're, they're autonomous. But also, you know, we, we're thinking about what is, what does it mean for it to be ambient. Right. Like it's, it's kind of when it has its own infrastructure and its own computer and its own ways to interact with it. How does that start to change what it can do? For example, like we have an API, so people are using it for all kinds of things, triggering it from, you know, when something happens. And you know, we saw an example where someone has, they're triggering Jules for, to do kind of all kinds of updates to their site and then they have a GitHub action that is going to automatically merge Juul's pull requests. So it's just like all kinds of stuff is flowing. You really kind of changing how people are able to do stuff.

captions.zh: 这个是和CLI有关的吗？
captions.en: Is that CLI related just to close that loop?

captions.zh: 对，我们有一个CLI，你知道的，我们想在开发者所在的地方和他们对接。API是可以从任何地方触发的，但是在本地工作时，你也希望能触发一些东西。所以我们推出了Joule CLI，几周前上线的，可以让你和它互动。等这个播客发布的时候，我们也会和Gemini CLI集成。
captions.en: Yeah, CLI says we also have a cli, which is, you know, we want to meet developers where they are. Right. And so part of the, you know, an API is like you can trigger it from anywhere, but also, you know, when you're working locally, like, you want to be able to trigger stuff. So we. Yep. So we have, we have the Joule CLI we launched a couple weeks ago, which lets you interact with it. By the time this podcast comes out, we'll be integrated with the Gemini cli. Jen.

captions.zh: 所以我在想，你们有好几个CLI，我不太确定具体怎么样。
captions.en: So I was thinking, like, you have a number of CLIs, I'm not sure exactly.

captions.zh: 好的，所以Gemini CLI，我们会在各种地方结合使用，充分利用这个力量。因为开发者在各个地方工作，所以要让这个自主的环境agent能够轻松地为你完成各种工作。
captions.en: Okay, so Gemini CLI, all kinds of places where we're going to kind of mix and be able to harness this power. Right. Because developers work in all kinds of spots and so making it easy to have this autonomous ambient agent that can really do all kinds of work for you.

captions.zh: 嗯，你们刚开始的时候，有没有什么假设很快就被推翻了？特别是在做Genai和编码agent方面？我猜你可能对这些不陌生，因为搜索引擎也用很多机器学习的“黑箱”技术，比如几年前的bert更新。对啊，给我们讲讲，你的AI工程之旅是怎样的？
captions.en: Yeah. What is your journey when you started out, did you find any assumptions that were quickly challenged when working with Genai and coding agents in general? I guess you're maybe not too unfamiliar with it because Search uses a lot of machine learned, black boxy type things, including bert, which was a major update a few years ago. Yeah. So, I mean, just fill us in. What is your AI engineering journey?

captions.zh: 对，完全没错。我觉得一直在显现的一个问题就是模型真的很重要。可能听起来显而易见，但模型的质量真的会影响你能做到什么，以及你怎么围绕它进行开发。比如说，我们一开始用的是比较早期的Gemini模型，那时候agent的架构特别复杂。我觉得我们看到的一个变化就是，随着模型的进步，架构变得越来越简单。有时候，这些架构几乎成了模型处理困难问题的拐杖。比如，我们尝试过非常复杂的子agent系统，也做过一些实验。
captions.en: Yeah, totally. So I think one of the things that keeps coming up is like the model makes such a difference. I mean, maybe it sounds obvious, but it's like the quality of the model really changes what you're able to do and how you engineer around it. So, for example, when we started this was with relatively early models of Gemini. We had the agent scaffolding around. It was incredibly complex. I think one of the things we've seen is scaffolds get simpler and simpler over time as the models get better. And in some ways the scaffolding is almost a crutch for things the model struggles with. For example, really complicated subagent systems. We've played with that, we've experimented with that.

captions.zh: 能举个例子，说说你们放弃过的某种子agent吗？
captions.en: Can you give an example of a kind of subagent that you had to abandon?

captions.en: I have this take on the different kinds of work. That is something I posted here on the semi async value of death where basically you kind of need to, on the extreme end you can delegate to async agents which Jules, cloud code, whatever. But then over here you kind of need the sort of deep involvement in understanding the code base and not vibe coding, whatever the opposite of it is. Actually, that's my talk, which is I've been thinking about this. So I tweeted out this phrase because I think I feel it's in the air that the term vibe coding was obviously coined by Andrej and he's super influential in February. And people have just come to kind of use it as a blank check to just YOLO on prompts and stuff and create the worst code imaginable and leave other people to clean it up. So I think people are kind of at their limits with this. It's probably maxed out in terms of popularity, but we don't have yet what's next. summary.zh: 播客深入探讨了AI对编程生产力的深远影响，以及自动化编码Agent在软件工程中的应用前景。嘉宾Jed Borovic分享了他在谷歌实验室的工作经历，并提出AI不仅能提高编程效率，还将塑造软件开发的新未来。
summary.en: The podcast delves into AI's profound impact on programming productivity and the future of automated coding agents in software engineering. Guest Jed Borovic shares his experiences at Google Labs, stating AI not only enhances coding efficiency but also shapes the future of software development.

keyPoints.title: AI不只是工具，而是未来创作的利器
highlights: AI可成为创作更好艺术的工具，而非威胁。
Jed选择了将AI视为提升创作的机会。
AI的应用正重新定义艺术创作的可能性。

keyPoints.title: 谷歌实验室的创新模式
highlights: 谷歌实验室开发不适合其他部门的新产品。
实验室与DeepMind紧密合作，打造AI产品。
这种合作模式助力谷歌在AI领域的持续创新。

keyPoints.title: 编码Agent的核心与未来
highlights: 未来的编码Agent将更强大，能处理复杂任务。
自动化Agent需有自己的计算环境来长时间运行。
这种设计将改变软件工程师的工作方式。

keyPoints.title: AI如何改变软件工程师的未来
highlights: AI工具将提升编程生产力和软件开发投资回报。
比起减少工程师，AI会创造更多开发机会。
未来的软件开发将更加高效灵活。

keyPoints.title: Agentic Coding是编程的未来
highlights: Agentic Coding可能是未来的编程范式。
强调与机器互动，促进需求的发现和满足。
这种模式有望替代传统的编程流程。
